body.draft-comment: This topic is designed to contains some customization tips.

section.title: Use one of the Predefined Placeholders to Insert Custom HTML Fragments
section.p: The WebHelp Responsive template contains a series of component placeholders. Some of these placeholders are left empty in the default output configurations, but you can use them to display custom content. You can use this method when you like an existing skin, but you need to change a bit the generated output.
Each such placeholder has an associated parameter in the transformation scenario Parameters tab. As a means of rapid identification, all these parameters have the name prefix webhelp.fragment.
For example, to insert a message above the search text field in the main page of the output, follow this procedure:

ol.li: Edit the WebHelp Responsive transformation scenario.
Go to Parameters tab and find the parameter associated with the place holder that you want to use. In our case, it is called webhelp.fragment.welcome.

Edit the parameter. Depending on the size of the content you want to add you can insert one of the following: a small well-formed XHTML fragment, such as: Welcome to our user guide. path to a file that contains a well-formed XHTML content.

section.title: Customizing WebHelp Output with a Custom CSS
section.p: You can use this method when you like an existing skin, and it is very close to what you need, so it is the perfect candidate for customization. Such a situation could be when you want change a color, where you want to adjust a little bit the margins or paddings.

ul.li: The custom CSS can be included in the project.

body.section:
Create a WebHelp Responsive skinThis method is useful when you need some design that is not similar to any of the oXygen predefined skins, or you want to heavily change one of the skins. Also this method is useful when you want to distribute additional resources (font, images) together with CSS.
Advantages
The resources are encapsulated into the skin directory, together with the CSS file
Appears in the transformation scenario dialog Themes tab.
Disadvantages
You need access to the installation folder, or to use an external DITA-OT, with the webhelp plugin installed.
Method
First of all you have to locate the DITA-OT you are using. (Look into the preferences for "DITA"). For instance if you are using DITA-OT 2.X, look into the folder:
{oXygenInstallDir}/frameworks/dita/DITA-OT2.x/plugins/com.oxygenxml.webhelp/templates/dita/bootstrap/variants/
Here you can see some subdirectories, corresponding to different variants of the same template. For instance:
tiles (the main page contains a section with tiles for each chapter)
tree (the main page contains a section with some expandable tree)
In each variant, you will find a directory with a collection of skins.
Copy the folder of one skin and change the skin.css file.
You can place fonts, images or other resources in the resources folder next to the skin.css file.
Tip: Use a small map for a speedy publishing time. Use the browser CSS inspector to lookup for CSS classes you need to modify.

Create a new Webhelp Responsive TemplateThis method can be used when you need to make significant structural changes, for instance moving some components to other positions, or you want to use a different layout library than Bootstrap (for instance switch to Foundation).
Advantages
Full customization is possible, change the structure of the generated HTML files and create multiple skins for the new template.
Disadvantages
You need access to the installation folder, or to use an external DITA-OT, with the webhelp plugin installed.
Method
Locate the DITA-OT you are using. (Look into the preferences for "DITA"). For instance if you are using DITA-OT 2.X, look into the folder:
{oXygenInstallDir}/frameworks/dita/DITA-OT2.x/plugins/com.oxygenxml.webhelp/templates/dita/
Copy the bootstrap folder, clean up the variants directory and keep just one. In that variant, keep just a skin. Modify the .html files, CSS-s, etc.
Tip: Use a small map for a speedy publishing time. Use the browser CSS inspector to lookup for CSS classes you need to modify.
